attachments.extracted_content:
I'll help you analyze this workshop outline and provide suggestions for improvement. Let me break this down systematically.
Current Structure Analysis:
The current workshop is 2 hours and 50 minutes long, focusing on design thinking and prototyping with marginalized communities.
Strengths:

Good flow from introduction to practical application
Interactive elements throughout (check-ins, chat sharing, icebreakers)
Mix of theory and practice
Includes both high-tech and grounded solutions
Bookended with reflection (opening word and closing word)
Includes case studies and real examples

Areas for Improvement:

Too compressed for community work - rushing through important topics
Many complex topics get only 5 minutes
Not enough time for relationship building
Limited time for actual prototyping work
Missing community context-setting
No breaks scheduled
No time allocated for cultural considerations

Recommendations for 2-Day Split:
Day 1 - Community Context & Design Thinking Foundations
Morning (9:00-12:30):

Opening ceremony/cultural considerations (30 min)
Introductions & community building (45 min)
Community context mapping (60 min)
Break (15 min)
Understanding prototyping in community context (60 min)

Afternoon (13:30-17:00):

Story sharing session (45 min)
Design thinking principles (60 min)
Break (15 min)
Local solution showcase (45 min)
Community feedback session (45 min)
Closing reflection (30 min)

Day 2 - Practical Application & Prototyping
Morning (9:00-12:30):

Opening check-in (30 min)
Review & reconnection (30 min)
Hands-on design thinking exercises (90 min)
Break (15 min)
Prototyping basics (45 min)

Afternoon (13:30-17:00):

Prototype development (90 min)
Break (15 min)
Community feedback session (45 min)
Action planning (45 min)
Closing ceremony (30 min)

Key Improvements:

More time for relationship building
Proper breaks included
Cultural considerations integrated
Extended time for actual prototyping
Community feedback sessions
Action planning for implementation
Opening and closing ceremonies
Balance between structure and flexibility

Additional Recommendations:

Include local community leaders in facilitation
Build in documentation methods
Consider accessibility needs
Plan for different literacy levels
Include movement activities
Provide materials in local languages
Create space for storytelling
Include evaluation components

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these aspects or focus on specific areas you'd like to develop further? CopyRetryBGIt's a zoom session and each person is in an different country working on their own projectEditAh, this changes the approach significantly! Let me revise my recommendations for a virtual, multi-timezone workshop with individual projects.
Key Considerations for Virtual Format:

Zoom fatigue - need shorter sessions with more breaks
Time zone management - participants from different countries
Virtual collaboration tools needed
Different internet connectivity levels
Individual project focus while maintaining group learning

Recommended 2-Day Structure:
DAY 1 - CONNECTION & CONTEXT
Session 1 (2.5 hours):

Virtual welcome & tech check (15 min)
Introduction & project sharing (30 min)
Community context presentation (20 min)
Break (10 min)
Interactive session: Mapping challenges (45 min)
Story highlight presentations (20 min)
Closing check-in (10 min)

Break (1.5 hours) - Offline project work
Session 2 (2.5 hours):

Energizer (10 min)
Design thinking principles (30 min)
Break (10 min)
Individual project work with group consultation (45 min)
Cross-regional solution sharing (45 min)
Day 1 reflection (10 min)

DAY 2 - PROTOTYPING & ACTION
Session 1 (2.5 hours):

Opening & reflection sharing (20 min)
Prototyping methods for virtual context (30 min)
Break (10 min)
Individual prototyping work (45 min)
Peer feedback sessions in small groups (35 min)
Closing check-in (10 min)

Break (1.5 hours) - Offline project work
Session 2 (2.5 hours):

Energizer (10 min)
Project iteration time (45 min)
Break (10 min)
Action planning presentation (20 min)
Individual action plan development (35 min)
Final sharing & next steps (20 min)

Technical Recommendations:

Use Miro/Mural for visual collaboration
Create breakout rooms for small group work
Use chat actively for ongoing engagement
Have alternative participation methods (chat, verbal, collaborative docs)
Record sessions for those who may have connectivity issues
Use asynchronous tools for between-session work

Engagement Strategies:

Pair participants across regions for peer feedback
Create smaller accountability groups in similar time zones
Use shared document for real-time documentation
Incorporate silent reflection time
Mix individual work with group sharing
Use polls and quick surveys for engagement
Create a virtual gallery of projects in progress

Would you like me to detail any specific segment or suggest specific activities for any part of this structure? CopyRetryBGLet's add some real depth, perhaps we can do breakouts where people talk about the problem and create a story and share it and see if they can get to really feel what drives them, what is the underlying value that fuels them Are there any quotes for this, bonus points if it's international rather than just western although western is fine tooEditYes! This kind of deep, values-based storytelling work is crucial for building authentic community solutions. Let me suggest a structured storytelling session that gets to the heart of people's motivations.
Values-Based Storytelling Workshop GuideClick to open document
This deep storytelling session would work well as the foundation for Day 1, helping participants connect with their core motivations before moving into solution design. The mix of proverbs and quotes from different traditions helps create an inclusive space while acknowledging ancient wisdom about storytelling and change.
We could then use these stories as touchstones throughout the workshop, returning to them when:

Evaluating potential solutions ("Does this honor your core value?")
Making design decisions ("Which option better serves the future you described?")
Facing challenges ("Remember why you started this work...")
Creating implementation plans ("How does this connect to your community's story?")

Would you like me to:

Develop specific facilitation techniques for virtual storytelling?
Add more structured exercises for getting to core values?
Create a framework for connecting stories to solution design?
Suggest ways to document and weave these stories throughout the workshop?
 CopyRetryBGhow can we add some of the design thinking loops streamlined into this so that it's not an abrupt transition? 
I'd like to talk about the importance of How might we questions, and also bring the idea of closeness with creativity and innovation and problem solving The title of the talk is: 
Prototyping With/In Marginalized Communities - Workshop Day 2Please join us for an interactive workshop exploring approaches to inclusive prototyping with marginalized communities.EditI'll help integrate design thinking loops with the storytelling approach to create a more fluid workshop experience.
Prototyping With/In Marginalized Communities - Workshop GuideClick to open document
This integrated approach:

Uses stories as the foundation for design research
Naturally flows into problem framing through "How Might We" questions
Leverages proximity and community knowledge for ideation
Keeps values at the center while moving into prototyping
Maintains an iterative, community-centered approach throughout

The key is that we're not teaching design thinking as a separate methodology, but rather showing how it naturally emerges from deep community engagement and storytelling.
Would you like me to:

Develop specific exercises for any of these sections?
Create more detailed facilitation guides?
Add example cases showing this flow in action?
Elaborate on any particular aspect?
 CopyRetry

00:00:08 Kalyan
We struggle with a common challenge. I mean, I, I, I'd say that I found one version of the answer to that.

00:00:20 Kalyan
I wouldn't say that would be the answer, but my work over pastedBGwhat insights, quotes, and content can we get from this interview with Kalayan?EditThis conversation with Kalyan reveals several profound insights about community-based education, sustainable development, and authentic motivation. Here are the key insights and notable quotes:
Key Themes & Insights:

Validation vs. Motivation


"Motivation is an effort, whereas it should work like gravity... it should be as effortless as a snowflake falling on the ground"
The idea that learning should be validated by community impact rather than external motivation


Education & Community Connection


The problem of education causing youth to "fall out of love with their village"
Villages as "lighthouses of indigenous wisdom"
The importance of maintaining cultural knowledge and local solutions


Applied Learning & Immediate Impact


The example of students using thermal physics to create better water bottles for shepherds
"Everything that they're learning here immediately serves a purpose"
Small solutions leading to bigger ambitions

Notable Quotes:

On Indigenous Wisdom:
"Villages have that indigenous wisdom... through culture leaves that wisdom of how to thrive in coexistence"
On Community Validation:
"If 1000 farmers benefit by my knowledge of physics... that motivates me to learn more without the facilitators having to motivate the kids"
On Purpose:
"Otherwise, I spend years learning calculus without knowing why the hell am I learning it"
On Community Design:
"How can we take the strengths of each community and get them to become very self reliant and get them to also be humble enough to depend on their neighboring community"

Practical Examples:

The Water Bottle Innovation:


Students used simple materials (Pepsi bottles and rock wool)
Applied thermal physics knowledge
Created immediate community impact
Led to continued innovation interest


Economic Model Goals:
"How do we build an economic system that incentivizes us to work on what really matters to us, like preserving what keeps us alive? And building what makes our life meaningful"

Framework Elements:

Education should:


Be immediately relevant to community needs
Create visible impact
Lead to community validation
Build on indigenous wisdom
Connect global concepts to local relevance


Community Development should:


Foster interdependence between communities
Balance self-reliance with connection
Preserve cultural wisdom
Create meaningful validation loops

This conversation provides valuable insights for designing community-based education and development programs that authentically connect learning with community impact and cultural preservation. Here are the key insights and notable quotes:

When the only tool you have every problem looks like a nail, that's why people so often make an "app for that" and today it will be AI solutions for that. Let's think more deeply and diversely and I'd like people to know what skills they have in the room from their cohorts to learn from and get support from - not only do they need to knjow the problem deeply, they need to get out of their own heads so they see they have more than a hammer to solve the problemEditYou raise an excellent point about avoiding single-tool thinking and fostering diverse problem-solving approaches. Let me help structure this into a workshop framework that encourages broader thinking while incorporating Kalyan's insights.
Beyond Single-Tool Solutions: Workshop FrameworkClick to open document
This framework helps participants:

Recognize their default problem-solving patterns
Explore diverse solution approaches
Connect solutions to community validation
Build on existing wisdom
Create immediate, visible impact

Would you like me to:

Develop specific exercises for any section?
Add more validation mechanisms?
Suggest ways to document the process?
Elaborate on any particular aspect?
 CopyRetryBGLet's also emphasize how beauty can also be a part of the solution, like the beautiful salsabil's which are water fountains that cool the air or court yards - 
Also another core part is to see if the problem itself can be the solution, for instance the problem of garbage and then founding fuze up to transform it into bags, etc - what other kinds of problems can be solutions can you find 5 cool projects that do that and 5 other ways that beauty is a core part of the solutionEditHere's an exploration of how problems can become solutions and how beauty can be integral rather than decorative:
Problems as Solutions - Real Examples:

Fuze Up (Iraq) - Transforms plastic waste into fashionable bags


The problem: Plastic pollution
The solution: Economic opportunity + waste reduction
Added value: Fashion and style makes recycling desirable


Orange Fiber (Italy) - Converts citrus waste into sustainable fabric


The problem: Massive citrus peel waste from juice industry
The solution: Luxury sustainable textiles
Added value: Created a whole new material category


Toast Ale (UK) - Turns wasted bread into craft beer


The problem: Bakery waste
The solution: Premium beverages
Added value: Raises awareness through enjoyable product


Mushroom Packaging (Ecovative) - Uses fungal growth for packaging


The problem: Agricultural waste
The solution: Biodegradable packaging
Added value: Natural aesthetics appeal to eco-conscious consumers


Plastic Bank - Transforms ocean plastic into currency


The problem: Ocean plastic + poverty
The solution: Economic system for recycling
Added value: Creates dignity through entrepreneurship

Beauty as Core Solution:

Salsabil Water Fountains (Islamic Architecture)


Functional: Cools air through evaporation
Beautiful: Creates soothing sounds and visual appeal
Cultural: Integrates spiritual significance with practical needs
Psychological: Sound of water reduces stress


Traditional Moroccan Riads


Functional: Natural cooling and privacy
Beautiful: Gardens, tilework, and fountains
Social: Creates community gathering spaces
Environmental: Passive cooling reduces energy needs


Living Root Bridges (Meghalaya, India)


Functional: Crosses rivers, gets stronger with time
Beautiful: Natural integration with environment
Cultural: Represents generational thinking
Educational: Teaches patience and natural engineering


Solar Trees (Various Locations)


Functional: Generates clean energy
Beautiful: Creates artistic landmarks
Educational: Makes energy production visible
Social: Creates gathering spaces under shade


Vertical Gardens (Patrick Blanc)


Functional: Improves air quality, reduces heat
Beautiful: Creates living art
Psychological: Connects urban spaces with nature
Environmental: Supports biodiversity

Key Principles for Integration:

Multi-solving:


Look for solutions that solve multiple problems
Find ways beauty can enhance function
Consider cultural and social benefits alongside practical ones


Natural Integration:


Learn from traditional architecture
Use local materials and patterns
Work with natural processes


Cultural Resonance:


Connect to local aesthetic traditions
Honor cultural practices
Create meaningful spaces


Social Impact:


Make solutions gathering points
Create opportunities for interaction
Build community pride


Educational Value:


Make processes visible
Create teaching opportunities
Inspire new thinking

This approach helps us see that:

Problems contain hidden resources
Beauty can be functional
Solutions can honor tradition while innovating
Design can serve multiple purposes simultaneously
Cultural practices often contain deep wisdom about sustainability

Would you like me to explore any of these examples in more detail or suggest additional ways to integrate these principles into the workshop? CopyRetryBGCan we get more traditional and international ideas for beauty and problem being the solution?
Also let's add a third one, where the solution is doing nothing, or doing less.EditLet me explore more traditional, international examples and add the wisdom of "less is more" or "doing nothing" as a solution type.
Traditional/International Problems as Solutions:

Terra Preta (Amazon) - Ancient civilizations turned poor soil and waste into super-fertile black earth


Problem: Poor soil + organic waste
Solution: Created artificial soil that's still fertile after 2000+ years
Added value: Carbon sequestration


Qanat Underground Canals (Iran/Middle East)


Problem: Water scarcity + hot climate
Solution: Underground water channels that use gravity
Added value: Created oasis communities and underground cool spaces


Chinampas (Aztec) - Floating gardens


Problem: Limited farmland + swamp areas
Solution: Created fertile artificial islands
Added value: Fish habitat + water filtration


Baolis (India) - Stepwells


Problem: Water access + heat
Solution: Combined water storage with community space
Added value: Beautiful architecture + social gathering place


Suikinkutsu (Japan) - Garden water feature


Problem: Excess water from washing hands
Solution: Created musical instrument from drips
Added value: Meditative sound art

Traditional/International Beauty as Core Solution:

Mughal Gardens (India/Pakistan)


Function: Food production + cooling
Beauty: Geometric patterns + fountains
Wisdom: Perfect proportions reduce water waste


Mashrabiya Screens (Middle East)


Function: Privacy + air conditioning
Beauty: Intricate geometric patterns
Wisdom: Pattern density varies by sun exposure


Yakhchal (Persian Ice Houses)


Function: Desert refrigeration
Beauty: Distinctive spiral shape
Wisdom: Form follows thermodynamics


Rice Terraces (Philippines/Indonesia)


Function: Mountain farming
Beauty: Living landscape art
Wisdom: Works with natural contours


Moai Statues (Easter Island)


Function: Mark freshwater sources
Beauty: Monumental sculpture
Wisdom: Cultural navigation markers

Solutions Through Non-Action:

Traditional Japanese Forest Management


Principle: "Do-nothing" farming
Action: Let forest self-manage
Wisdom: Nature knows best
Result: Healthier forests than managed ones


Desert Bedouin Lifestyle


Principle: Move with seasons
Action: Don't build permanent structures
Wisdom: Adapt to nature rather than changing it
Result: Sustainable desert living


Traditional Fallow Field Practices


Principle: Rest the land
Action: Don't plant sometimes
Wisdom: Soil needs recovery time
Result: Better long-term yields


Mediterranean Siesta


Principle: Rest during heat
Action: Don't work mid-day
Wisdom: Adapt to climate
Result: Energy efficiency + community time


Traditional Prairie Management


Principle: Let it burn
Action: Don't stop natural fires
Wisdom: Fire is part of ecosystem
Result: Healthier prairies

Key Insights:

Ancient Solutions Often:


Work with natural cycles
Create multiple benefits
Build community
Last for generations


Beauty in Traditional Design:


Serves practical purposes
Communicates cultural values
Creates social spaces
Uses local materials


Non-Action Wisdom:


Sometimes less is more
Nature has solutions
Patience brings results
Observation before action

This reminds us that:

Ancient solutions were often more sophisticated than we realize
Beauty and function are traditionally united
Sometimes the best solution is to step back
Local wisdom often contains deep understanding of ecosystems

Would you like me to:

Explore any of these examples in more detail?
Find more examples from specific regions?
Develop ways to incorporate these principles into modern solutions?
Create exercises to help people identify when non-action might be best?
 CopyRetryPlease review the following context and identify my goals, themes, and needs for a 2 day 2.5 hour workshop. Ask me 10 questions to help you create a smooth workshop flow. I will add the context and thpastedBG
EditBased on the comprehensive context you've provided, I'll analyze your workshop goals, themes, and key needs. Then I'll ask 10 strategic questions to help create a smoother workshop flow.
Key Goals:

Bridge theory and practice in prototyping for marginalized communities
Integrate multiple approaches to problem-solving beyond tech solutions
Emphasize validation through community impact
Connect learning directly to community needs
Balance design thinking with indigenous wisdom and local solutions

Core Themes:

Validation vs. Motivation
Beauty as Functionality
Problems as Solutions
The Power of Doing Less
Multiple Forms of Capital
Community Connection and Impact

10 Strategic Questions:

How can we modify the opening to immediately establish the connection between personal stories and design thinking, perhaps incorporating Kalyan's concept of "validation through impact"?
The current ice breaker focuses on imagination - should we adapt it to include more community storytelling elements while keeping the playful energy?
Your slides include multiple frameworks (Einstein's problem-solving, Jobs' problem definition, etc.) - how can we streamline these to create a clearer narrative thread?
Would it be valuable to include a segment where participants identify different forms of capital in their communities before starting the design process?
The current flow moves quickly between concepts - should we restructure to give more time for depth in fewer areas rather than covering many topics briefly?
How can we integrate the "beauty as solution" examples more naturally into the design thinking process rather than treating them as separate case studies?
The current workshop includes many individual exercises - should we incorporate more pair or small group work to build on the collective wisdom in the room?
Could we create space for participants to identify and share examples of "doing less" solutions from their own communities?
The closing currently focuses on individual feelings - should we expand it to include community impact reflections?
How can we better integrate the practical prototyping exercises with the various theoretical frameworks (8 forms of capital, problems as solutions, etc.) without overwhelming participants?

Would you like me to explore any of these questions in more depth or propose specific modifications to the workshop structure? CopyRetryBG1) I think we can do that by going into breakouts and sharing a story of gratitude to start? Or starting quickly with some breakouts so people notice it's not a day for being by themselves without sharing
1. yeah, would love to keep the playful element and connect it with stories and feelings and attention and values in a simple way
2. these are just going to be background elements so it's nice
3. yeah, that would be awesome, what resources do people have. we need to redefine marginalized, what is marginalized, where is the margin? 
4. yeah, let's see what the essentials are and focus on that - the design thinking framework I tohught could be for day 2
5. i like the idea of talking about beauty, there is no problem, and do nothing as solutions to help with creativity and see if we can use this to look at their problems and to find a "beautiful, problem is the solution, or do nothing solution" for their challenge 
6. yeah, i was thinking to do more things in breakouts
7. yeah, love that idea suggesting to do that in answer six here
8. yeah, i think i'd like to bring in the community more somehow, what knowledge do we have and skills and abilities 
9. I think the practical can be seen as a way of getting deeper stories and a framework to DO things with a time limit because that can enhance creativity. which reminds me I'd like to do a 10 ideas / paper clip creativitiy ice breaker in the startEditGreat feedback! Let me propose a revised flow incorporating these ideas:
Opening Sequence (30 mins):

Quick Welcome & Paperclip Challenge (10 mins)


10 ideas in 2 minutes: "What can you do with a paperclip?"
Share most creative ideas in chat
Links to: creativity under constraints, reframing problems


Breakout Storytelling (20 mins)


Groups of 3-4
Share a story of gratitude from your community
Listen for: values, attention points, what makes people come alive
Return and share key insights

Redefining Margins & Resources (45 mins):

Community Asset Mapping (25 mins)


Use 8 forms of capital framework
In breakouts: "What resources do we have?"
Challenge assumption of "marginalized"
Where is the center? Who decides?


Collective Skills Inventory (20 mins)


What knowledge exists in our group?
Create shared document of expertise
Include non-traditional skills and wisdom

Alternative Solutions Framework (45 mins):
Present and explore three solution types with examples:

Beautiful Solutions


Salsabils & courtyards
Design that serves multiple purposes
Beauty as functionality


Problem as Solution


Waste to resource examples
Local success stories
Finding value in challenges


Do-Nothing Solutions


Fukuoka's natural farming
Traditional wisdom examples
When less is more

Applying Frameworks (45 mins):
Breakout Activity:

Each group takes one community challenge
Generate solutions using all three frameworks
Share and get feedback
Focus on storytelling and practical application

Would you like me to:

Detail any specific section?
Develop specific prompts for the breakouts?
Create a visual flow for the session?
Add more examples for any framework?

This structure emphasizes:

Starting with connection
Challenging assumptions
Multiple ways of seeing solutions
Practical application
Community wisdom
Group learning

How does this align with your vision? CopyRetryBGWhat if we also had an element where we added the importance of getting out of your head/finding different ways to think about the problem, analyzing it and looking at the different scales, and levers one can hold on to to identify solutions and that involves education, perhaps using AI to help break down a problem into its ocmponents to see which is the most managable part to work on or other people's experiences and knowledge can bring more hammers screwdriers and chisels to bear to the probelmEditYes! Adding systematic problem analysis and different thinking modalities can help people get unstuck and see new angles. Here's how we could integrate this:
Breaking Down Problems Module (45 mins):

Multiple Scales Analysis (15 mins)


Individual level
Family/Group level
Community level
Systemic/Policy level
Global connections

Activity: Have groups map their challenge across these scales, identifying:

Key stakeholders at each level
Potential intervention points
Resources/constraints
Ripple effects


Different Thinking Modes (15 mins)
Introduce various ways to analyze the same problem:


Physical lens (infrastructure, materials, space)
Social lens (relationships, power dynamics)
Economic lens (resources, incentives)
Cultural lens (traditions, values)
Environmental lens (natural systems)
Technical lens (processes, tools)


Finding Leverage Points (15 mins)
Interactive Exercise:


Use collective knowledge in breakouts
Each person looks at the problem through their expertise lens
Share different tools/approaches from their experience
Map potential intervention points from each perspective

For example, a waste management problem could be seen as:

Infrastructure challenge (physical)
Behavior change opportunity (social)
Business opportunity (economic)
Cultural shift needed (cultural)
Ecosystem impact (environmental)
Process optimization (technical)

This helps participants:

Break large problems into manageable pieces
See multiple entry points for solutions
Leverage collective wisdom
Identify where their skills best apply
Find unexpected connections

Would you like me to:

Develop specific exercises for any section?
Create example worksheets?
Add more thinking frameworks?
Design breakout activities?
 CopyRetryBGI'd like to tell them what i'll tell them, tell them, and then tell them I told them. can you add this framework, what are the things I'm sharing in broad principles, can you make the braod strokes layout and then write out the plan with timestamps and other facilitation queues and supportsEditLet me break this down into a clear "tell them what you'll tell them, tell them, then tell them what you told them" framework, followed by a detailed facilitation plan.
Core Principles Being Shared:

Multiple Ways to Solve Problems


Beyond tech/apps/AI solutions
Beauty as solution
Problems as solutions

Using different thinking lenses

Redefining "marginalized"
8 forms of capital
Collective wisdom
Indigenous solutions
Local expertise


Getting Out of Our Own Way


Breaking down problems
Multiple scales thinking
Different perspectives

Moving from complexity to actionable steps

Let me create a detailed facilitation plan with timestamps. Would you like me to:

Structure the specific opening/middle/closing messaging for each principle?
Create a detailed timeline with facilitation notes?
Design support materials (slides, worksheets, breakout instructions)?
Add specific examples and stories to illustrate each principle?

Which format would be most helpful for your workshop preparation? CopyRetryBG[Josephine (White Hat): Information & Facts] What essential factual background or examples do participants need upfront on Day 2 so they fully understand the transition from values/storytelling to the prototyping phase?[Claude (Green Hat): Creativity & Possibility] What creative ice-breaker or storytelling exercise can we use at the start of Day 2 to spark participants’ imaginations and help them recall Day 1’s insights?[Prunella (Black Hat): Potential Problems] What potential barriers or misunderstandings might participants have when forming their “How might we” questions, and how can we preemptively address those?[Percy (Yellow Hat): Positivity & Opportunities] How can we highlight the positive potential of each participant’s unique skill set and cultural background to foster a sense of opportunity and collective strength?[Cyril (Red Hat): Emotions & Empathy] How can we ensure participants remain emotionally connected to the communities they’re designing for, keeping empathy at the heart of their prototypes?[Quackers (Blue Hat): Synthesis & Structure] In what order should we introduce the concepts of multiple forms of capital, minimal intervention strategies, and the incorporation of beauty to ensure a cohesive learning flow?[Josephine (White Hat) Follow-up] What key data or case studies (e.g., Protovillage, EcoAct, Tonlé, HomeBiogas) are most relevant and culturally accessible for your participants, considering their diverse global backgrounds?[Claude (Green Hat) Follow-up] Which hands-on prototyping activities will best encourage participants to “think with their hands” and step out of their comfort zones, while still aligning with time constraints?[Prunella (Black Hat) Follow-up] What troubleshooting guidance or reflection prompts will help participants refine prototypes if they find their initial ideas too complex, costly, or misaligned with community needs?[Percy (Yellow Hat) Follow-up] How can we celebrate the participants’ progress and new insights at the end of Day 2 in a way that reinforces a positive, forward-looking mindset, and encourages them to continue iterating after the workshop ends?
These questions are designed to help you refine the flow, content, and activities of your 2-day workshop to ensure participants gain both the inspiration and the practical tools to design with and for marginalized communities.
You said:I think by day two they should have their creativty empowered and a clear compelling story that matters to them that has a value attached to it that motivates and captivates their attention 2. we can do the paperclip ideation ice breaker asking how many uses for a paper clip in 2 mins and do it again after telling them it's a test of writing speed 3. they might get stuck on only one element of the problem and not think of other ways to address it 4. we can share and highlight people in the main room to share 5. they should pay attention to what grabs their attention and understand the underlying emotion 6. i'd love your help deciding, i think the three elements of minimal intervention, beauty, and the problem is the solution should be in a section about creative problem solving together 7. protovillage is a friend so it's good, I like AirInk too, i like the corckscrew self planting seed project demonstrating the biomimicry prinicple as well 8. drawing is what we'll focus on, perhaps we'll need a drawing ice breaker on day two 9. they go on to a longer program which is fine for them to be slowEditBased on your responses, let me propose a clear framework and detailed facilitation plan.
Opening Message (Day 2 Morning):
"Yesterday, we explored your stories, values, and what makes you come alive. Today, we'll channel that energy into creative problem-solving using three powerful approaches: finding beauty in solutions, turning problems into solutions, and sometimes doing less rather than more. We'll also practice looking at problems from multiple angles to find unexpected opportunities."

Prototyping With/In Marginalized Communities - Day 2
Detailed Facilitation Timeline
9:00-9:30 | Opening & Creativity Warmup
Copy9:00-9:05 | Welcome Back
- Quick energetic welcome
- Acknowledge that some may be tired from deep work yesterday
- Frame today as moving from stories to creative possibilities

9:05-9:20 | Paper Clip Challenge
Facilitation Notes:
- Have paper and pens ready
- Use online timer visible to all
- Round 1: "Write as many uses for a paper clip as you can in 2 minutes"
- Share a few fun examples
- Round 2: Frame as "This is actually a writing speed test"
- Compare results, discuss how reframing changes outcomes

Story to Share: The Protovillage water bottle example
- Students saw a standard water bottle
- Reframed it as a thermal physics challenge
- Created immediate community impact
9:30-10:15 | Creative Problem-Solving Frameworks
Copy9:30-9:45 | Beauty as Solution
Examples to Share:
1. Salsabil Fountains
- Beautifies space
- Cools air
- Creates soothing sounds
- Serves cultural purposes

2. Traditional Courtyard Designs
- Natural cooling
- Community gathering
- Privacy
- Urban agriculture

Facilitation Notes:
- Show visuals if possible
- Ask for examples from participants' cultures
Copy9:45-10:00 | Problem as Solution
Examples to Share:
1. Air-Ink
- Turns air pollution into artist materials
- Creates economic opportunity
- Reduces pollution
- Raises awareness

2. Protovillage Educational Model
- "Village as school"
- Learning through solving community problems
- Validation through impact

Facilitation Notes:
- Emphasize how problems contain hidden resources
- Ask for local examples
Copy10:00-10:15 | Minimal Intervention
Examples to Share:
1. Traditional Forest Management
- "Do-nothing" farming
- Natural balance
- Reduced labor
- Better outcomes

2. Desert Architecture
- Working with climate
- Natural ventilation
- Passive cooling
- Traditional wisdom

Facilitation Notes:
- Challenge "more is better" thinking
- Share Fukuoka's farming principles briefly
10:15-10:30 | Break

Put on energizing music
Encourage movement
Set clear return time

10:30-11:45 | Multiple Perspectives Exercise
Copy10:30-10:40 | Framework Introduction
Present different lenses:
- Physical/Material
- Social/Cultural
- Economic
- Environmental
- Technical

10:40-11:10 | Breakout Groups
Facilitation Notes:
- Groups of 4-5
- Each person shares their challenge
- Group helps map different perspectives
- Look for unexpected connections
- Identify potential intervention points

11:10-11:30 | Gallery Walk
- Each group posts their insights
- Participants browse other groups' work
- Note patterns and insights

11:30-11:45 | Harvest Insights
- What surprised you?
- What new possibilities emerged?
- What connections did you discover?
11:45-12:00 | Closing Integration
CopyFacilitation Notes:
- Recap three main approaches:
  * Beauty as solution
  * Problem as solution
  * Minimal intervention
- Highlight key examples shared
- Preview next steps in their journey
- End with gratitude

input.title: Prototyping With/In Marginalized Communities - Workshop Day 2
input.content:
# Prototyping With/In Marginalized Communities
## Workshop Day 2: From Stories to Solutions

### Opening (30 mins)
- Quick energizer: Drawing icebreaker to transition into visual thinking
- Recap of Day 1 key principles: Beauty, Truth, Love
- Share selected reflections from participants' forum posts

### Creative Problem-Solving Framework (45 mins)
- Introduce three solution approaches:
  1. Beauty as Solution (Example: Salsabil fountains)
  2. Problem as Solution (Example: Air-Ink)
  3. Minimal Intervention (Example: Traditional forest management)
- Interactive exercise: Analyzing examples through these three lenses
- Group discussion: How might these approaches apply to participants' challenges?

### Break (15 mins)

### Multiple Perspectives Exercise (45 mins)
- Map challenges across different scales:
  - Individual level
  - Family/Group level  
  - Community level
  - Systemic level
- Apply different thinking lenses:
  - Physical/Material lens
  - Social/Cultural lens
  - Economic lens
  - Environmental lens
  - Technical lens
- Breakout groups: Help each other identify potential intervention points

### Rapid Prototyping Session (45 mins)
- Introduction to quick visualization techniques
- Paper prototyping materials ready
- Focus on "showing" rather than "telling"
- Emphasis on iteration and feedback
- Remember: "The solution should be the less important part"

### Break (15 mins)

### Community Feedback Practice (30 mins)
- Role-play receiving feedback
- Practice pivoting and adapting
- Focus on listening for underlying needs
- Connect back to Day 1's storytelling principles

### Integration & Next Steps (15 mins)
- Review how beauty, truth and love can guide prototyping
- Connect to 8 forms of capital framework
- Planning concrete next steps
- Preview of longer program ahead

### Materials Needed:
- Drawing supplies
- Paper prototyping materials
- Breakout room setup
- Feedback capture templates
- Next steps planning sheets

### Facilitation Notes:
- Keep energy high with movement between sessions
- Balance structure with flexibility
- Create space for emergence
- Connect everything back to values and principles
- Maintain focus on relationship-building

Diy SustainabilityMonth-long hackathon

DIY Sustainability
City Growers
This is Team Wasabi. We were formed on January 9, 2015 with a 2-fold mission. The first is to help design some useful solutions for our practitioner, City Growers. The second is to connect City Growers with relevant resources and skills so they can later innovate their own solutions. 

Team Wasabi consists of 
Becca  
Nse
Muffin
Ted
Doug
Luvena

Basically, we’re a team with a very diverse set of skills. Over the past month, we’ve been working with local community organizers - City Growers to try to solve some of the problems they face in urban farming in Boston. City Growers is a great organization that works to convert unused lots into urban farms in order to grow local, nutritious food for the community.

As you might imagine, small scale farming can be quite challenging in Boston where land is expensive, many restrictions are in place, and winters are harsh. But, we hope to be able to improve their processes. 

City Growers
Over the past month, we’ve been working with local community organizers - City Growers to try to solve some of the problems they face in urban farming in Boston. City Growers is a great organization that works to convert unused lots into urban farms in order to grow local, nutritious food for the community.

City Growers’ mission is to transform vacant lots in Boston into intensive urban farms that are economically and environmentally sustainable.
We combine the resources of community organizations, neighborhood associations and local markets for fresh produce to accomplish our major goals:
Creating employment for community members at livable wages
Addressing food security issues by increasing local agricultural production capacity
Increasing local access to affordable, nutrient-rich foods
City Growers is contributing to the new green economy in communities where economic revitalization is needed most.  In the coming years, we will create a checkerboard of productive green space in Boston’s inner city (more than twenty acres of 1/4 to 1-acre lots) where local growing talent thrives.


Challenges and Opportunities
Some of the challenges they presented were:
decreasing time spent on weeding
reducing costs associated with seedlings
increasing crop yields
improving efficiency of wash station
increasing compost (access)

The ideas/desires Bobby and Nataka voiced included: 
Greenhouse 
Better wash station
Improved watering systems (appropriate for different vegetables, convenient)
Tools/devices to make composting, harvesting and weeding easier
Bike/harvesting/mobile farm stand
Virtual farm tour


Problem Framing
Ultimately, we prioritized three potential problems: 

Decreasing weeds
Improving watering systems
Improving washing stations

In further conversations with City Growers, we realized that the biggest problem, by a significant margin, was weed control. Out of this, our problem statement was born:  

How can we decrease the time spent weeding? 



Once we arrived at the problem statement, we spent some time brainstorming methods of overcoming this - including whether a solution needed to focus more on preventing the growth of weeds or improving the weed removal process. After proposing a few ideas and talking with Bobby, we learned more about City Growers’ current process. They remove weeds manually and with hand tools. This process is slow and time-consuming. However, because the farm plots are so small (around ¼ acre, roughly twice the size of a basketball court), it is often easier to do things by hand than with machines.

Unfortunately, many of the commercially available hand tools are not optimal for their processes. Ideally, they would have some double-headed tools and/or interchangeable tools to make the weeding process easier.  

Through discussions with City Growers, we realized that a potential solution is to design a workshop for the associated Urban Farming Institute program to teach urban farmers how to make their own tools. Such a workshop will not only allow for farmers to obtain customized tools but will also empower and provide these small scale farmers with skills to later prototype and build their own equipment. 

These tools will address each of the following problems:

Ergonomics - Existing commercially available tools are fairly standard in size. As a result, they may not be optimal in weight, height, or shape/angle of the tool for best maneuverability.
Customizability - Small scale farmers often have limited land space, so crops are planted in very close proximity. As a result, many of the commercially available weeding tools are too large for their needs (they’re too large to fit between individual seedlings or rows). Additionally, they lack modularity. Farmers can potentially also innovate new designs for more rapid/efficient work. 
Economics - A big factor for small scale farms is cost. The operating budget is relatively small, so any achievable savings will help. City Growers currently has fewer tools than they have workers, and more specialized tools can be expensive if purchased from a distributor


Initial Ideas
Handle
Attachment Point
Head
We first focused on interchangeable attachment points.  The advantages of having tools that are easily attached to and detached from their handles are (a) workers who are using multiple tools have less to carry around, and (b) each worker can use a handle length that’s appropriate for his/her needs.  We prototyped 4 models: 
Screw
Clamp
Pin
Spring-tensioned




User Feedback
After receiving feedback in favor of the pin option from Bobby and Trist, we narrowed our focus to the pin design and improving its usability. 

Additionally, we did some cardboard prototyping with Bobby and Trist to create tool-heads. Four different tools were designed:
Narrow Action Hoe
Double-headed Common Hoe and Cultivator
Double-headed Collinear Hoe and Spade
Seeding Plate

What did you observe in Tainan Fablab workshops?
I was a little nervous to start with Design Thinking as the topic. Because some people said that compared to Design Thinking, technical practice may be more attractive. But after the beginning of the course, I found that students can understand the importance of the reason behind a creation, and try to improve social problems through their works. I saw teams who are very creative and artistic, including a group called “Soul Box"（魂 Box）. They noticed the low-wage issues of Taiwan and created a pressure relief mask. Users can enjoy screaming to release the pressure with head buried inside. The work is not just an idea, but also an observation of society. By the way, we did yoga before the start of the workshop. Perhaps it is nothing to do with their work, but everyone was very involved.

Let's play "Imagination in Action"! 
Form a circle: We'll stand in a circle, and one by one, each person gets to be the "director." 
Share a scene: Share a fun scene from your imagination, It could be anything – silly, magical, or totally out there!  
Act it out: The rest of us have a minute to bring it to life using just our bodies and creativity. 
Have fun! Don't worry about being perfect; it's all about having fun and letting our imaginations run wild. 

What is design for?

Design Thinking Case Study: GE


What is innovation for?

instagram.com/p/smaAQugnGN/
What did you observe in Tainan Fablab workshops?
I was a little nervous to start with Design Thinking as the topic. Because some people said that compared to Design Thinking, technical practice may be more attractive. But after the beginning of the course, I found that students can understand the importance of the reason behind a creation, and try to improve social problems through their works. I saw teams who are very creative and artistic, including a group called “Soul Box"（魂 Box）. They noticed the low-wage issues of Taiwan and created a pressure relief mask. Users can enjoy screaming to release the pressure with head buried inside. The work is not just an idea, but also an observation of society. By the way, we did yoga before the start of the workshop. Perhaps it is nothing to do with their work, but everyone was very involved.


Design Thinking
A few key principals:
Diverge 
(lots of ideas!)
Converge 
(test those ideas with your stakeholder!)
Think with your hands
Understand problem before you solve it
Role play  / “Empathy”
Diverse Teams
Having a process frees the mind to be creative (constraints)
Role of space in design


Design Thinking Games / Ice breakers!
30 Circles
Fridge
Bear VS Lion
10 Ideas 2 min challenge

Design Thinking
Let’s go through the whole process right now :)

1. 4 min Each - Get Story!
Interview partner, start with idea or theme. But, get to a story.
Your observation:
 


2. 3 mins Each
Expand on one story:
Notes/Sketches:

3. 4 mins - Imagine the meaning
Notice something then infer what it means.
I wonder if this means: …
It’s interesting/telling/surprising that she/he …

4. 3 mins - Create Questions
Restate the inferences.
“How might be” questions:
How might we: …
How might we: …
How might we: …
Be Curious!

5. 5 mins - Sketch Time!
Sketch at least 4 different ideas

6. 4 mins Each - Share Solutions/Capture Feedbacks
Let them look and understand what your drawing
Feedback:
1.
2. 
3.

7. 3 mins - Sketching Time!
Sketch your big idea
And flesh it out!

8. 7 mins
Build it!

9. 4 mins Each - Observation
Observe them and interacting with your creation!
=
Good
Change
‘s
‘s

How was it?

Observations?

Turning Desires into Dollars
Pain and Pleasure is where value comes from in a business.

Design thinking ensures companies create products that relate to the needs and and desires of their customers. 
Involve customers early to build things that get sold.


Questions and Discussions

CLOSING CIRCLE

In one word, how do you feel now compared to the start?

THANK YOU!!!


Does anyone have any questions? 

E: bg@bilalghalib.com
Ph: +1 478 227 2253 

Feel free to take insights adn tell me where my facilitation fell flat and where it was great and take those insights to update the current slides to a much better workshop for day 2

input.title: Prototyping With/In Marginalized Communities - Day 2 Workshop Flow
input.content:
# Day 2: From Stories to Solutions

## Opening (30 mins)
- Drawing icebreaker: Collaborative sketching exercise 
- Quick physical movement/dance to reconnect group energy
- Share key reflections from Day 1 (focus on beauty, truth, love framework)

## Creative Problem-Solving Framework (45 mins)
Introduce three solution approaches through storytelling:
1. Beauty as Solution
   - Share Salsabil fountain example
   - How beauty solves multiple problems elegantly
2. Problem as Solution  
   - Share Air-Ink story
   - Finding value in "waste"
3. Minimal Intervention
   - Share Fukuoka's natural farming principles
   - When doing less is more

## Multiple Perspectives Mapping (45 mins)
Interactive exercise in breakout rooms:
- Map challenges across different scales/lenses
- Use 8 forms of capital framework to identify resources
- Help each other see blind spots and opportunities
- Focus on local wisdom and existing solutions

## Break (15 mins)

## Rapid Prototyping Workshop (60 mins)
- Quick demo of paper prototyping techniques
- Work in small groups
- Focus on "showing" rather than "telling"
- Multiple quick iterations
- Regular feedback rounds

## Closing Integration (30 mins) 
- Gallery walk of prototypes
- Connect solutions back to Day 1 principles
- Action planning
- Community commitments

## Key Principles to Weave Throughout:
- Balance structure with spontaneity
- Keep energy high with movement
- Ground everything in stories
- Make space for emergence
- Focus on relationships and collective wisdom
- Maintain playful creativity while being practical
- Connect to deeper values and meaning

## Materials Needed:
- Drawing supplies
- Paper prototyping materials
- Breakout room setup
- Music playlist
- Documentation templates

## Notes for Facilitator:
- Watch energy levels
- Encourage cross-pollination of ideas
- Make space for questions and discussion
- Keep connecting back to stories and values
- Help participants trust the process

Diy SustainabilityMonth-long hackathon

DIY Sustainability
City Growers
This is Team Wasabi. We were formed on January 9, 2015 with a 2-fold mission. The first is to help design some useful solutions for our practitioner, City Growers. The second is to connect City Growers with relevant resources and skills so they can later innovate their own solutions. 

Team Wasabi consists of 
Becca  
Nse
Muffin
Ted
Doug
Luvena

Basically, we’re a team with a very diverse set of skills. Over the past month, we’ve been working with local community organizers - City Growers to try to solve some of the problems they face in urban farming in Boston. City Growers is a great organization that works to convert unused lots into urban farms in order to grow local, nutritious food for the community.

As you might imagine, small scale farming can be quite challenging in Boston where land is expensive, many restrictions are in place, and winters are harsh. But, we hope to be able to improve their processes. 

City Growers
Over the past month, we’ve been working with local community organizers - City Growers to try to solve some of the problems they face in urban farming in Boston. City Growers is a great organization that works to convert unused lots into urban farms in order to grow local, nutritious food for the community.

City Growers’ mission is to transform vacant lots in Boston into intensive urban farms that are economically and environmentally sustainable.
We combine the resources of community organizations, neighborhood associations and local markets for fresh produce to accomplish our major goals:
Creating employment for community members at livable wages
Addressing food security issues by increasing local agricultural production capacity
Increasing local access to affordable, nutrient-rich foods
City Growers is contributing to the new green economy in communities where economic revitalization is needed most.  In the coming years, we will create a checkerboard of productive green space in Boston’s inner city (more than twenty acres of 1/4 to 1-acre lots) where local growing talent thrives.


Challenges and Opportunities
Some of the challenges they presented were:
decreasing time spent on weeding
reducing costs associated with seedlings
increasing crop yields
improving efficiency of wash station
increasing compost (access)

The ideas/desires Bobby and Nataka voiced included: 
Greenhouse 
Better wash station
Improved watering systems (appropriate for different vegetables, convenient)
Tools/devices to make composting, harvesting and weeding easier
Bike/harvesting/mobile farm stand
Virtual farm tour


Problem Framing
Ultimately, we prioritized three potential problems: 

Decreasing weeds
Improving watering systems
Improving washing stations

In further conversations with City Growers, we realized that the biggest problem, by a significant margin, was weed control. Out of this, our problem statement was born:  

How can we decrease the time spent weeding? 



Once we arrived at the problem statement, we spent some time brainstorming methods of overcoming this - including whether a solution needed to focus more on preventing the growth of weeds or improving the weed removal process. After proposing a few ideas and talking with Bobby, we learned more about City Growers’ current process. They remove weeds manually and with hand tools. This process is slow and time-consuming. However, because the farm plots are so small (around ¼ acre, roughly twice the size of a basketball court), it is often easier to do things by hand than with machines.

Unfortunately, many of the commercially available hand tools are not optimal for their processes. Ideally, they would have some double-headed tools and/or interchangeable tools to make the weeding process easier.  

Through discussions with City Growers, we realized that a potential solution is to design a workshop for the associated Urban Farming Institute program to teach urban farmers how to make their own tools. Such a workshop will not only allow for farmers to obtain customized tools but will also empower and provide these small scale farmers with skills to later prototype and build their own equipment. 

These tools will address each of the following problems:

Ergonomics - Existing commercially available tools are fairly standard in size. As a result, they may not be optimal in weight, height, or shape/angle of the tool for best maneuverability.
Customizability - Small scale farmers often have limited land space, so crops are planted in very close proximity. As a result, many of the commercially available weeding tools are too large for their needs (they’re too large to fit between individual seedlings or rows). Additionally, they lack modularity. Farmers can potentially also innovate new designs for more rapid/efficient work. 
Economics - A big factor for small scale farms is cost. The operating budget is relatively small, so any achievable savings will help. City Growers currently has fewer tools than they have workers, and more specialized tools can be expensive if purchased from a distributor


Initial Ideas
Handle
Attachment Point
Head
We first focused on interchangeable attachment points.  The advantages of having tools that are easily attached to and detached from their handles are (a) workers who are using multiple tools have less to carry around, and (b) each worker can use a handle length that’s appropriate for his/her needs.  We prototyped 4 models: 
Screw
Clamp
Pin
Spring-tensioned




User Feedback
After receiving feedback in favor of the pin option from Bobby and Trist, we narrowed our focus to the pin design and improving its usability. 

Additionally, we did some cardboard prototyping with Bobby and Trist to create tool-heads. Four different tools were designed:
Narrow Action Hoe
Double-headed Common Hoe and Cultivator
Double-headed Collinear Hoe and Spade
Seeding Plate

What did you observe in Tainan Fablab workshops?
I was a little nervous to start with Design Thinking as the topic. Because some people said that compared to Design Thinking, technical practice may be more attractive. But after the beginning of the course, I found that students can understand the importance of the reason behind a creation, and try to improve social problems through their works. I saw teams who are very creative and artistic, including a group called “Soul Box"（魂 Box）. They noticed the low-wage issues of Taiwan and created a pressure relief mask. Users can enjoy screaming to release the pressure with head buried inside. The work is not just an idea, but also an observation of society. By the way, we did yoga before the start of the workshop. Perhaps it is nothing to do with their work, but everyone was very involved.

Let's play "Imagination in Action"! 
Form a circle: We'll stand in a circle, and one by one, each person gets to be the "director." 
Share a scene: Share a fun scene from your imagination, It could be anything – silly, magical, or totally out there!  
Act it out: The rest of us have a minute to bring it to life using just our bodies and creativity. 
Have fun! Don't worry about being perfect; it's all about having fun and letting our imaginations run wild.

input.title: Day 2 Detailed Facilitation Guide
input.content:
# Day 2: From Stories to Solutions
## Detailed Facilitation Guide

### Opening (30 mins)

#### Reflecting Back Day 1 Insights (10 mins)
Show participant quotes:
- "Self conscious is the enemy of creativity" 
- "We become scared to expand our thoughts in fear of being judged"
- "Less creativity because we are taught something has a specific use"
- "Experiencing the problem yourself is so important"

Key themes from Day 1:
- Truth, Beauty, Love as guiding principles
- Listening deeply before understanding
- Going beyond intended uses
- The Room's collective wisdom

#### Drawing Creativity Exercise (20 mins)
1. Give everyone paper and drawing tools
2. Step 1 (2 mins): "Draw a house quickly"
3. Step 2 (3 mins): "Now draw a house without lifting your pen from the paper"
4. Step 3 (5 mins): "Draw a house that expresses joy"
5. Share in pairs (5 mins)
6. Group reflection (5 mins):
- How did constraints change your creativity?
- What happened when emotion entered the process?

### Design Thinking Core (45 mins)

#### From Stories to Solutions Framework
Show participant insight: "I think working with marginalized communities can sometimes turn the usual challenges of prototyping exponential, you may meet more resistance, or realize there are more factors you weren't able to see at first"

Present three approaches:
1. Beauty as Solution
2. Problem as Solution  
3. Minimal Intervention

#### Interactive Exercise: Solution Mapping (30 mins)
Have groups map their challenge across different capital types shared yesterday:
- Social Capital
- Cultural Capital
- Experiential Capital 
- Spiritual Capital
- Intellectual Capital

### Prototyping Session (45 mins)

#### Quick Visualization Rules
1. No words allowed - only drawings
2. 2 minutes per sketch
3. Quantity over quality
4. Build on others' ideas

#### Breakout Process
1. Share challenge (2 mins each)
2. Silent sketching round (5 mins)
3. Present sketches without speaking (2 mins each)
4. Group builds on favorite elements (10 mins)
5. Rapid prototype with available materials (15 mins)

### Closing Integration (30 mins)

#### Gallery Walk (15 mins)
- Post prototypes 
- Silent observation
- Written feedback

#### Final Reflection (15 mins)
Prompt with Day 1 quote: "Don't ask yourself what the world needs, ask yourself what makes you come alive"
- What makes your prototype come alive?
- What truth does it serve?
- What beauty does it hold?

### Facilitation Notes
- Keep energy high with movement between sections
- Use music during transitions
- Make space for laughter and play
- Connect everything back to Day 1 principles
- Watch for signs of judgment or self-consciousness
- Help participants trust the process

### Your Forms of Capital

You shared these as your strongest currencies:

- Experiential Capital

- Intellectual Capital
- Spiritual Capital

## Today's Journey: From Stories to Solutions

### Our Guiding Principles
Beauty → Truth → Love

As you noted:
> "Experiencing the problem yourself is so important" - Rosemary

### Design Process 
Building on your insight:

Today we'll:

This reminds us to:

### Let's Begin!
"Letting go of what you know so that you can listen enough before understanding how things can be different."

input.title: Drawing Exercise: From Stories to Sketches
input.content:
# From Stories to Sketches
## Drawing Exercise Guide (20 mins)

### Opening Setup (2 mins)
- Share Georgina's insight: "The first one was more like thinking smart like a 'grown-up', the second was like go wild and I was just laughing while doing it"
- Explain: Just like with the paperclip exercise, we'll practice letting go of "grown-up thinking"

### Round 1: Current Reality (3 mins)
"Draw how you see your challenge right now"
- Quick sketches
- No judgment
- First thoughts

### Round 2: Multiple Capitals (5 mins)
Share Lucy's quote: "The people I have met along the way have really inspired me. My community as a whole"

Instructions:
- Draw same challenge but show different types of resources available
- Include social connections (inspired by Ricardo's insight about "Creating different narratives from the same story")
- Show cultural elements
- Add experiential wisdom

### Round 3: Beauty & Truth (5 mins)
Share Maureen's quote: "My Ahaaa moment was 'Don't ask yourself what the world needs, ask yourself what makes you come ALIVE'"

Instructions:
- Draw what makes your heart sing about this challenge
- Show the beauty you want to create
- Express what feels true

### Sharing in Pairs (5 mins)
- Partner 1 describes what they see in Partner 2's progression of drawings
- Partner 2 shares what they were trying to express
- Switch roles

### Facilitation Notes
- Play light music during drawing
- Remind people of Bill's insight: "The moment you start thinking about it you are 'done'" - encourage flow over thought
- Echo Deborah's wisdom: "Our creativity is kinda eroded once we are exposed to structured information. The creative side works best when there's no limit"
- If people seem stuck, remind them of Nyasha's joy: "I totally enjoyed the session it felt like a mini fun holiday"

### Materials Needed
- Paper (3 sheets per person)
- Colorful markers/pens
- Music playlist
- Timer
- Quotes displayed on slides

### Key Principles
- No right/wrong way to draw
- Focus on expression over perfection 
- Draw from heart not head
- Let creativity flow freely

### Connection to Next Activity
This leads into prototyping by:
- Loosening up creative muscles
- Practicing visual thinking
- Connecting heart to hands
- Building on Day 1's insights
- Creating safety for creative expression

input.title: Simple Drawing Warmup
input.content:
# Drawing Warmup (15 mins)

### Setup
- Everyone gets paper and pen/marker
- Keep it light and playful
- No art skills needed!

### Flow

1. Quick Warmup (2 mins)
"Let's wake up our hands! Draw circles without lifting your pen"
- Just get the hands moving
- Feel free to laugh
- No pressure

2. Simple Shapes Challenge (3 mins)
"Draw these basic shapes in different ways":
- A house (30 seconds)
- A tree (30 seconds)
- A sun (30 seconds)
- A heart (30 seconds)
- Free choice! (30 seconds)

3. Quick Story (5 mins)
"Pick your favorite shape and turn it into a mini-story with 3 quick drawings"
- First drawing: The shape as is
- Second drawing: Add something to it
- Third drawing: Transform it into something else entirely

4. Share & Laugh (5 mins)
- Show your mini-story to a partner
- Tell them what happened
- Just have fun with it!

### Facilitation Tips
- Keep energy light
- Use music
- Celebrate silly drawings
- If people seem stuck, remind them "We're just playing!"
- Move quickly between steps

### Why This Works
- Builds confidence through simple shapes
- Creates safety through play
- Warms up creative muscles
- Gets people laughing together
- Natural progression from simple to story

### Next Step
"Now that our hands are warmed up, let's use drawing to explore our ideas..."

"""Prototyping In/With Marginalized Communities

Day 1: Stories, Values & Expanding Perspectives

Abraham 
Maslow

Howard Thurman
Don’t ask yourself what the world needs; ask yourself what makes you come alive. And then go and do that. Because what the world needs is people who have come alive.

Howard Thurman
When was the last time you really came alive came alive, let’s go into breakouts and share. What values do you think you were living? 

Who am I?

POC21Sustainability 
Camp

Anthony de 
Mello
You have to understand, my dears, that the shortest distance between truth and a human being is a story.

Diy SustainabilityMonth-long hackathon

DIY Sustainability
City Growers
This is Team Wasabi. We were formed on January 9, 2015 with a 2-fold mission. The first is to help design some useful solutions for our practitioner, City Growers. The second is to connect City Growers with relevant resources and skills so they can later innovate their own solutions. 

Team Wasabi consists of 
Becca  
Nse
Muffin
Ted
Doug
Luvena

Basically, we’re a team with a very diverse set of skills. Over the past month, we’ve been working with local community organizers - City Growers to try to solve some of the problems they face in urban farming in Boston. City Growers is a great organization that works to convert unused lots into urban farms in order to grow local, nutritious food for the community.

As you might imagine, small scale farming can be quite challenging in Boston where land is expensive, many restrictions are in place, and winters are harsh. But, we hope to be able to improve their processes. 

City Growers
Over the past month, we’ve been working with local community organizers - City Growers to try to solve some of the problems they face in urban farming in Boston. City Growers is a great organization that works to convert unused lots into urban farms in order to grow local, nutritious food for the community.

City Growers’ mission is to transform vacant lots in Boston into intensive urban farms that are economically and environmentally sustainable.
We combine the resources of community organizations, neighborhood associations and local markets for fresh produce to accomplish our major goals:
Creating employment for community members at livable wages
Addressing food security issues by increasing local agricultural production capacity
Increasing local access to affordable, nutrient-rich foods
City Growers is contributing to the new green economy in communities where economic revitalization is needed most.  In the coming years, we will create a checkerboard of productive green space in Boston’s inner city (more than twenty acres of 1/4 to 1-acre lots) where local growing talent thrives.


Challenges and Opportunities
Some of the challenges they presented were:
decreasing time spent on weeding
reducing costs associated with seedlings
increasing crop yields
improving efficiency of wash station
increasing compost (access)

The ideas/desires Bobby and Nataka voiced included: 
Greenhouse 
Better wash station
Improved watering systems (appropriate for different vegetables, convenient)
Tools/devices to make composting, harvesting and weeding easier
Bike/harvesting/mobile farm stand
Virtual farm tour


Problem Framing
Ultimately, we prioritized three potential problems: 

Decreasing weeds
Improving watering systems
Improving washing stations

In further conversations with City Growers, we realized that the biggest problem, by a significant margin, was weed control. Out of this, our problem statement was born:  

How can we decrease the time spent weeding? 



Once we arrived at the problem statement, we spent some time brainstorming methods of overcoming this - including whether a solution needed to focus more on preventing the growth of weeds or improving the weed removal process. After proposing a few ideas and talking with Bobby, we learned more about City Growers’ current process. They remove weeds manually and with hand tools. This process is slow and time-consuming. However, because the farm plots are so small (around ¼ acre, roughly twice the size of a basketball court), it is often easier to do things by hand than with machines.

Unfortunately, many of the commercially available hand tools are not optimal for their processes. Ideally, they would have some double-headed tools and/or interchangeable tools to make the weeding process easier.  

Through discussions with City Growers, we realized that a potential solution is to design a workshop for the associated Urban Farming Institute program to teach urban farmers how to make their own tools. Such a workshop will not only allow for farmers to obtain customized tools but will also empower and provide these small scale farmers with skills to later prototype and build their own equipment. 

These tools will address each of the following problems:

Ergonomics - Existing commercially available tools are fairly standard in size. As a result, they may not be optimal in weight, height, or shape/angle of the tool for best maneuverability.
Customizability - Small scale farmers often have limited land space, so crops are planted in very close proximity. As a result, many of the commercially available weeding tools are too large for their needs (they’re too large to fit between individual seedlings or rows). Additionally, they lack modularity. Farmers can potentially also innovate new designs for more rapid/efficient work. 
Economics - A big factor for small scale farms is cost. The operating budget is relatively small, so any achievable savings will help. City Growers currently has fewer tools than they have workers, and more specialized tools can be expensive if purchased from a distributor


Initial Ideas
Handle
Attachment Point
Head
We first focused on interchangeable attachment points.  The advantages of having tools that are easily attached to and detached from their handles are (a) workers who are using multiple tools have less to carry around, and (b) each worker can use a handle length that’s appropriate for his/her needs.  We prototyped 4 models: 
Screw
Clamp
Pin
Spring-tensioned




User Feedback
After receiving feedback in favor of the pin option from Bobby and Trist, we narrowed our focus to the pin design and improving its usability. 

Additionally, we did some cardboard prototyping with Bobby and Trist to create tool-heads. Four different tools were designed:
Narrow Action Hoe
Double-headed Common Hoe and Cultivator
Double-headed Collinear Hoe and Spade
Seeding Plate


Prototyping

instagram.com/p/smaAQugnGN/
What did you observe in Tainan Fablab workshops?
I was a little nervous to start with Design Thinking as the topic. Because some people said that compared to Design Thinking, technical practice may be more attractive. But after the beginning of the course, I found that students can understand the importance of the reason behind a creation, and try to improve social problems through their works. I saw teams who are very creative and artistic, including a group called “Soul Box"（魂 Box）. They noticed the low-wage issues of Taiwan and created a pressure relief mask. Users can enjoy screaming to release the pressure with head buried inside. The work is not just an idea, but also an observation of society. By the way, we did yoga before the start of the workshop. Perhaps it is nothing to do with their work, but everyone was very involved.


Tell your story.Whose problem are you solving. Why does it matter to you?
